title: Grazing Management  NDSU Extension Spring 2021 Horse Management Webinar Series

tasks.task: Evaluate and manage horse pasture grazing at various stages and species.
subtasks: Familiarize with common horse pasture grasses, such as smooth bromegrass, Kentucky bluegrass, Crested wheatgrass, and intermediate wheatgrass. Monitor grass quality and palatability at different growth stages.
Understand fertilizing needs for pastures, emphasizing nitrogen application (40-80 lbs actual N per acre) at optimal timing (late April to mid-May) for maximum benefits and to reduce volatilization.

Identify and manage toxic plants, including maple trees (leaves toxic to horses), choke cherries (cyanide toxicity), horsetail, locoweed, milkweed, oak trees, and nitrate accumulators like kochia, Russian thistle, and lambs quarter.

tasks.task: Implement integrated weed management strategies for horse pastures, including cultural practices (soil health, overseeding with favorable mixes), chemical control (herbicide application), and mechanical control (mowing).
subtasks: Select appropriate seed mixtures (e.g., bromegrass, orchard grass, wheatgrass, alfalfa) based on climate and soil conditions for maintaining high-quality forage.
Practice rotational grazing or managed grazing to prevent overgrazing and promote grass growth, adhering to drought management strategies and considering pasture soil health.

tasks.task: Evaluate and manage horse pasture grazing at various stages and species.
subtasks: Familiarize with common horse pasture grasses, such as smooth bromegrass, Kentucky bluegrass, Crested wheatgrass, and intermediate wheatgrass. Monitor grass quality and palatability at different growth stages.

tasks.task: Understand fertilizing needs for pastures, emphasizing nitrogen application (40-80 lbs actual N per acre) at optimal timing (late April to mid-May) for maximum benefits and to reduce volatilization.

Implement integrated weed management strategies for horse pastures, including cultural practices (soil health, overseeding with favorable mixes), chemical control (herbicide application), and mechanical control (mowing).
subtasks: Select appropriate seed mixtures (e.g., bromegrass, orchard grass, wheatgrass, alfalfa) based on climate and soil conditions for maintaining high-quality forage.
Practice rotational grazing or managed grazing to prevent overgrazing and promote grass growth, adhering to drought management strategies and considering pasture soil health.

tasks.task: Transition horses gradually to spring grasses to prevent digestive issues (e.g., colic) associated with rapid dietary changes. Monitor for signs of laminitis in at-risk horses.

Identify and manage toxic plants (e.g., maples, choke cherries, horsetail, locoweed) that pose risks to horses. Use preventive strategies such as selecting alternate forages, avoiding stressed plants, or physical removal.
Maintain nutrient balance by selecting the right fertilizers (e.g., nitrogen). Test soil and adjust application rates based on results. Time applications for early spring to avoid loss.
Evaluate and manage horse pasture grazing at various stages and species.**
Practice rotational grazing and managed grazing.**
Transition horses to spring grass safely.**
